>   But, in "MibuGishiDen", why they look so poor ???

Shinsengumi was paid, but they weren't paid a great deal. Receiving reward 
money from the Emperor for, say, distinguished service at the 8.18.1863 
incident, or the Ikedaya incident, was a big thing-- THAT was big money. 
Another issue to bear in mind is that these men started out poor, so even if 
they received a lot of money, they wouldn't go about making themselves *not* 
look poor right away.

Later on, when they were paid by the Shogunate, they also weren't paid an 
incredibly high amount...but they were better off than before (this appears 
in Mibugishiden-- the Shinsengumi go through "bakushin toritate"-- which 
means they are made hatamoto, or retainers of the Shogun). The best off the 
Shinsengumi were going to be monetarily and status-wise, at least on paper, 
was right before they headed to fight the Imperial army in Kai Province. 
Kondou was to become a daimyo with a 100,000 koku income, Hijikata would 
have 50,000, the captains would have 30,000, and the junior officers 10,000 
(see page 102 of Kikuchi Akira's "Toba-Fushimi no Tatakai Kara Nagareyama 
Made," in "Saitou Hajime no Subete) However, this was never to become 
reality.

>   Could anybody tell me, except "Kiyokawa Hachirou/Serizawa Kamo's probs", 
>are there another >internal problem in Shinsengumi????

Yes. There were periodically issues with people leaving. Also, early on, 
there was the issue of Okura Isetake, Arakida Samanosuke, and Kusunoki 
Kojuro, the Choshu spies who joined Shinsengumi early on, and were killed in 
the fall of 1863. (see Itou Tetsuya's timeline which appears at the end of 
the book "Saitou Hajime no Subete".) Most famous is the incident of Itou 
Kashitarou's group leaving-- this would later come back to haunt Kondou, who 
was shot by the survivors of the group in early 1868 (see page 157 of 
Nagakura Shinpachi's "Shinsengumi Tenmatsuki"). Another survivor of that 
group, Kano Washio, was the man who positively identified the newly captured 
Kondou later that year. Here is a picture of him: 
http://www.dokidoki.ne.jp/home2/quwatoro/syashin/kanou.jpg

There were also many other people who were executed for various reasons. 
However, Nagakura records even those who were executed on the memorial that 
he inscribed for Shinsengumi, a translation of which appears here: 
http://www.shinsengumihq.com/ShinsengumiMonument.htm

I hope that helps answer your questions.

-M.
